title: CVPR_2004_30_abs

sentences.text: Background modeling is an important component of many vision systems .
Existing work in the area has mostly addressed scenes that consist of static or quasi-static structures .
When the scene exhibits a persistent dynamic behavior in time , such an assumption is violated and detection performance deteriorates .
In this paper , we propose a new method for the modeling and subtraction of such scenes .
Towards the modeling of the dynamic characteristics , optical flow is computed and utilized as a feature in a higher dimensional space .
Inherent ambiguities in the computation of features are addressed by using a data-dependent bandwidth for density estimation using kernels .
Extensive experiments demonstrate the utility and performance of the proposed approach .

Entity-this_paper.label: this paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a novel method for modeling and subtracting dynamic scenes in vision systems, addressing the challenges posed by persistent dynamic behavior and utilizing optical flow as a feature in a higher dimensional space.

Entity-the_modeling_of_the_dynamic_chara.label: the modeling of the dynamic characteristics
aliases: the modeling of the dynamic characteristics
Entity-the_modeling_of_the_dynamic_chara.description: The modeling of the dynamic characteristics refers to the process of analyzing and representing the time-varying behaviors of scenes in vision systems, specifically through the computation of optical flow as a feature in a higher dimensional space to improve detection performance in dynamic environments.

mentions.local_name: the modeling of the dynamic characteristics

Entity-method.label: method
Entity-method.description: The method refers to a novel technique for modeling and subtracting dynamic scenes in vision systems, utilizing optical flow as a feature and addressing ambiguities in feature computation through data-dependent bandwidth for density estimation.

modeling and subtraction of such scenes
Entity-modeling_and_subtraction_of_such_.description: The phrase 'modeling and subtraction of such scenes' refers to a proposed method for analyzing and differentiating dynamic scenes in computer vision by utilizing optical flow and advanced density estimation techniques.

mentions.local_name: modeling and subtraction of such scenes
the modeling and subtraction of such scenes

Entity-dynamic_characteristic.label: dynamic characteristics
Entity-dynamic_characteristic.description: The term 'dynamic characteristics' refers to the temporal behaviors and changes in scenes that exhibit persistent motion, which are modeled using optical flow as a feature in higher dimensional space for improved background modeling in vision systems.

Entity-modeling.label: modeling
Entity-modeling.description: The term 'modeling' refers to the process of creating a new method for representing and analyzing dynamic scenes in vision systems, specifically through the computation of optical flow and the application of density estimation techniques.

Entity-a_feature_in_a_higher_dimensional.label: a feature in a higher dimensional space
aliases: a feature in a higher dimensional space
Entity-a_feature_in_a_higher_dimensional.description: In the context of the paper, 'a feature in a higher dimensional space' refers to the representation of optical flow data that captures dynamic characteristics of scenes, allowing for improved modeling and subtraction of persistent dynamic behaviors in vision systems.

mentions.local_name: a feature in a higher dimensional space

Entity-feature.label: features
Entity-feature.description: In this context, 'features' refers to the computed characteristics derived from optical flow that are utilized in a higher dimensional space for modeling dynamic behaviors in vision systems.

Entity-background_modeling.label: Background modeling
Entity-background_modeling.description: Background modeling is a technique used in computer vision to distinguish between foreground and background elements in visual data.

Entity-computation_of_feature.label: computation of features
Entity-computation_of_feature.description: The computation of features refers to the process of extracting and quantifying relevant characteristics from data, such as optical flow in dynamic scenes, which are then used for modeling and analysis in computer vision systems.

Entity-dynamic_behavior.label: dynamic behavior
Entity-dynamic_behavior.description: Dynamic behavior refers to the persistent changes in a scene over time that challenge the assumptions of static or quasi-static modeling in vision systems, leading to decreased detection performance.

Entity-optical_flow.label: optical flow
Entity-optical_flow.description: Optical flow is a computer vision technique used to estimate the motion of objects between consecutive frames in a video sequence by analyzing the apparent motion of brightness patterns.

Entity-persistent_dynamic_behavior.label: persistent dynamic behavior
Entity-persistent_dynamic_behavior.description: Persistent dynamic behavior refers to the continuous and time-varying changes in a scene that challenge the assumptions of static or quasi-static structures in vision systems, leading to decreased detection performance.

Entity-scene.label: scenes
Entity-scene.description: In the context of vision systems, 'scenes' refer to visual environments or settings that are primarily characterized by their static or quasi-static structures, which are the focus of background modeling techniques.

utility and performance of the proposed approach
Entity-utility_and_performance_of_the_pr.description: The mention 'utility and performance of the proposed approach' refers to the effectiveness and practical applicability of the new method for modeling and subtracting dynamic scenes in vision systems, as demonstrated through extensive experimental evaluations.

mentions.local_name: utility and performance of the proposed approach
the utility and performance of the proposed approach

Entity-performance.label: performance
Entity-performance.description: In this context, 'performance' refers to the effectiveness and utility of the proposed method for background modeling in vision systems, as evaluated through extensive experiments.

Entity-the_scene.label: the scene
Entity-the_scene.description: The scene refers to a visual environment characterized by persistent dynamic behavior over time, which poses challenges for detection performance in vision systems.

Entity-data-dependent_bandwidth.label: data-dependent bandwidth
Entity-data-dependent_bandwidth.description: Data-dependent bandwidth refers to a statistical parameter used in density estimation that adapts the bandwidth of kernel functions based on the characteristics of the data, allowing for more accurate modeling of features in dynamic scenes.

Entity-kernel.label: kernels
Entity-kernel.description: In this context, 'kernels' refer to mathematical functions used for density estimation that adaptively adjust their bandwidth based on the data, facilitating the modeling of dynamic characteristics in vision systems.

Entity-the_area.label: the area
Entity-the_area.description: the area refers to the field of background modeling in vision systems, specifically focusing on scenes with static or quasi-static structures.

Entity-detection_performance.label: detection performance
Entity-detection_performance.description: Detection performance refers to the effectiveness and accuracy of a system or algorithm in identifying and recognizing specific objects or events within a given dataset or environment.

Entity-utility.label: utility
Entity-utility.description: In this context, 'utility' refers to the measure of usefulness and effectiveness of the proposed method for modeling and subtracting dynamic scenes in vision systems, as demonstrated through extensive experiments.

Entity-vision_system.label: vision systems
Entity-vision_system.description: Vision systems are technological frameworks designed to interpret and analyze visual information from the environment, often utilizing sensors and algorithms to perform tasks such as object recognition, tracking, and scene understanding.

Entity-density_estimation_using_kernel.label: density estimation using kernels
Entity-density_estimation_using_kernel.description: Density estimation using kernels is a non-parametric statistical method that estimates the probability density function of a random variable by smoothing data points with kernel functions.

Entity-static_or_quasi-static_structure.label: static or quasi-static structures
Entity-static_or_quasi-static_structure.description: Static or quasi-static structures refer to elements in a scene that remain largely unchanged over time, allowing for effective background modeling in vision systems.

Entity-ambiguity.label: ambiguities
Entity-ambiguity.description: The term 'ambiguities' refers to the inherent uncertainties and complexities that arise during the computation of features in the context of background modeling in vision systems.

Entity-extensive_experiment.label: Extensive experiments
Entity-extensive_experiment.description: Extensive experiments refer to comprehensive and rigorous testing conducted to evaluate the effectiveness and performance of the proposed method for modeling and subtracting dynamic scenes in vision systems.

Entity-density_estimation.label: density estimation
Entity-density_estimation.description: Density estimation is a statistical technique used to estimate the probability distribution of a random variable based on observed data.

Entity-subtraction.label: subtraction
Entity-subtraction.description: Subtraction is a mathematical operation that represents the process of taking one quantity away from another, resulting in a difference.

Entity-higher_dimensional_space.label: higher dimensional space
Entity-higher_dimensional_space.description: A higher dimensional space is a mathematical concept that extends the idea of traditional three-dimensional space to include additional dimensions, allowing for the representation and analysis of complex data and features in various fields such as mathematics, physics, and data science.

Entity-quasi-static_structure.label: quasi-static structures
Entity-quasi-static_structure.description: Quasi-static structures are physical entities that undergo slow changes or deformations, allowing them to be approximated as static for the duration of the analysis.

Entity-computation.label: computation
Entity-computation.description: Computation refers to the process or method of performing mathematical calculations or processing data to derive results or insights.

Entity-proposed_approach.label: proposed approach
Entity-proposed_approach.description: The proposed approach refers to a specific research method or technique that has been suggested to address a particular problem or improve performance in a given field.

Entity-experiment.label: experiments
Entity-experiment.description: Experiments are systematic investigations conducted to test hypotheses, evaluate outcomes, or explore phenomena, often involving controlled conditions and variable manipulation.

Entity-existing_work.label: Existing work
Entity-existing_work.description: Existing work refers to prior research and academic contributions in a specific field or area of study.

summary: Background modeling is an important component of many vision systems . Existing work in the area has mostly addressed scenes that consist of static or quasi-static structures . When the scene exhibits a persistent dynamic behavior in time , such an assumption is violated and detection performance deteriorates . In this paper , we propose a new method for the modeling and subtraction of such scenes . Towards the modeling of the dynamic characteristics , optical flow is computed and utilized as a feature in a higher dimensional space . Inherent ambiguities in the computation of features are addressed by using a data-dependent bandwidth for density estimation using kernels . Extensive experiments demonstrate the utility and performance of the proposed approach .

Predicate-is_a_component_of.label: is a component of
Predicate-is_a_component_of.description: The predicate 'is a component of' indicates a relationship where the subject is an integral part or element that contributes to the overall functionality, structure, or operation of the object. It signifies that the subject plays a significant role within the broader context represented by the object, suggesting that the object cannot be fully realized or understood without the inclusion of the subject.

Predicate-has_addressed.label: has addressed
Predicate-has_addressed.description: The predicate 'has addressed' indicates that the subject has engaged with, discussed, or provided solutions to the issues, topics, or elements represented by the object. It implies a level of consideration or focus on the object by the subject, suggesting that the subject has contributed to the understanding or resolution of the object in some manner.

Predicate-consist_of.label: consist of
Predicate-consist_of.description: The predicate 'consist of' indicates a relationship where the subject is composed of or made up of the elements represented by the object. It implies that the object is an integral part of the subject, contributing to its overall structure or nature.

Predicate-exhibits.label: exhibits
Predicate-exhibits.description: The predicate 'exhibits' serves to indicate that the subject demonstrates, displays, or reveals certain characteristics, qualities, or behaviors represented by the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject is actively showcasing or manifesting the attributes described by the object, suggesting a visible or observable connection between the two.

Predicate-proposes.label: proposes
Predicate-proposes.description: The predicate 'proposes' indicates that the subject puts forward a suggestion, idea, or plan for consideration or action regarding the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject is actively recommending or introducing the object as a potential solution, approach, or concept to be evaluated or implemented.

Predicate-is_for.label: is for
Predicate-is_for.description: The predicate 'is for' establishes a relationship of purpose or intended use between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject serves a specific function or is designed to achieve the objectives described by the object. In this context, the subject is associated with a particular application or goal, suggesting that the object represents what the subject is meant to facilitate or accomplish.

Predicate-is_computed_and_utilized_as_a_.label: is computed and utilized as a feature in
Predicate-is_computed_and_utilized_as_a_.description: This predicate indicates that the subject undergoes a computational process that results in a specific output, which is then employed as a characteristic or attribute within a broader context or framework represented by the object. It highlights the transformation of the subject into a usable element that contributes to the functionality or analysis within the specified domain.

Predicate-is_utilized_as_a_feature_in.label: is utilized as a feature in
Predicate-is_utilized_as_a_feature_in.description: The predicate 'is utilized as a feature in' indicates that the subject serves a specific role or function as a characteristic or component within the context of the object. This relationship suggests that the subject contributes to or enhances the capabilities of the object, often in a technical or analytical framework, where the subject is applied or integrated into a broader system or model.

Predicate-is_computed_and_utilized_as.label: is computed and utilized as
Predicate-is_computed_and_utilized_as.description: The predicate 'is computed and utilized as' indicates a relationship where the subject is processed or calculated to serve a specific purpose or function represented by the object. This implies that the subject undergoes a transformation or analysis that enables it to be applied or interpreted in a particular context, thereby enhancing its utility or relevance in that context.

Predicate-are_addressed_by_using.label: are addressed by using
Predicate-are_addressed_by_using.description: The predicate 'are addressed by using' indicates a relationship where the subject is being dealt with or resolved through the application or implementation of the object. It suggests that the object serves as a method, tool, or approach that effectively tackles the issues or challenges represented by the subject.

Predicate-is_used_for.label: is used for
Predicate-is_used_for.description: The predicate 'is used for' establishes a functional relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject serves a specific purpose or application represented by the object. It implies that the subject is a tool, method, or resource that facilitates or enables the achievement of the objective denoted by the object.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates that the subject employs or utilizes the object as a means, method, or tool to achieve a specific purpose or function. It establishes a relationship where the subject actively incorporates the object into its processes or activities.

Predicate-is_performed_using.label: is performed using
Predicate-is_performed_using.description: The predicate 'is performed using' establishes a relationship where the subject represents a specific action, process, or method, and the object denotes the tools, techniques, or resources employed to carry out that action. It indicates that the subject cannot be executed without the involvement of the object, highlighting the dependency of the action on the means utilized.

Predicate-demonstrate.label: demonstrate
Predicate-demonstrate.description: The predicate 'demonstrate' serves to establish a relationship where the subject provides evidence or proof of the characteristics, qualities, or effectiveness of the object. It indicates that the subject's actions or findings substantiate the claims made about the object, thereby validating its significance or functionality.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is introducing, showcasing, or delivering information, findings, or concepts related to the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject actively communicates or reveals the content of the object to an audience, often in a formal or structured manner.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or concept that falls under the more general category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a wider scope or range of meanings, of which the subject is a part.
